Award.AbstractNarration:
A conference on "Arithmetic of Function Fields" will take place June 26-30, 2017, at the University of Muenster, Germany.
The purpose of this conference is to bring together international experts in a variety of areas of arithmetic geometry, automorphic forms, and function field arithmetic. The emphasis of the conference will be on recent spectacular developments in the theory of Drinfeld moduli spaces, Drinfeld modular forms, and their applications. It is hoped that having at the same place and time a large number of researchers with different viewpoints on function field arithmetic will illuminate previously unnoticed connections within the area, thus facilitating future progress. The organizers of the conference will make a strong effort to ensure an active participation of a large number of junior researchers and underrepresented groups.

Since their emergence in 1970s, Drinfeld moduli spaces had a tremendous impact on the Langlands program leading to a successful resolution of the global and local Langlands conjectures over function fields. Over the last few years, there has been an explosion of activity in function field arithmetic, with many spectacular results on special values of higher derivatives of L-functions of automorphic forms, special values of Carlitz-Goss L-functions, and Drinfeld modular forms. Moreover, new tantalizing connections have been discovered between different topics of function field arithmetic, such as special values of characteristic p zeta functions, deformations of Drinfeld modular forms, and function field analogue of Fontaine's theory. In many of these works, Drinfeld moduli spaces play a prominent role.
These developments, along with possible future directions of research, will be addressed by the invited speakers of this conference with the hope to inspire new generations to take part in this important and very active area of Number Theory.

Conference website: http://wwwmath.uni-muenster.de/sfb878/activities/AFF_announce.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
An international conference entitled Arithmetic of Function Fields took place in June 26-30 of 2017 at the Institute of Mathematics of the University of Muenster (IMUM), Germany. The conference was organized by

  • Ahmad El-Guindy (Texas A&M University at Qatar, Qatar) 
  • Ernst-Ulrich Gekeler (Saarland University, Germany)
  • Urs Hartl (University of Muenster, Germany)
  • Mihran Papikian (PI, Pennsylvania State University, USA)

The emphasis of the conference was on Drinfeld moduli spaces and the closely related topic of Drinfeld modular forms.There has been an explosion of activity in this area in the past few years, with many different themes being developed independently at the same time, so it was quite timely to have a gathering of some of the leading experts on function field arithmetic, modular varieties, automorphic forms, and arithmetic geometry at large to share their recent discoveries and to explore possible new directions of research.

Having at the same place and time a large number of researchers with different viewpoints on function field arithmetic illuminated previously unnoticed connections within the area, thus facilitating future progress.

The conference was funded by NSF ($15,000), IMUM (15,000 Euros) and Elsevier (15,000 Euros).

There were 27 lectures at the conference. A complete list of speakers, the titles of their talks and abstracts can be found on the conference websitewww.uni-muenster.de/SFB878/activities/AFF_announce.html 

A typical daily schedule consisted of 6 or 7 lectures, half of which were 60-minute long and the other half 30-minute long. All invited speakers were encouraged to make their talks accessible. The slides of 8 talks were posted on the conference website to allow for wide dissemination across the entire mathematical community. There were two 45- minute coffee breaks and a 2-hour lunch break to allow informal discussions among conference participants.

There were 77 participants at the conference, 13 of which were from universities in the United States. These included a diversity of mathematicians, male and female, junior and senior. Special efforts were made to invite female participants and speakers. There were 14 women participants, 4 of which were invited speakers.

NSF funding ensured a robust number of participants from United States at this international conference on a very active area of research in number theory. The NSF grant ($15,000) was used to fund 9 participants from United States, 4 of which were women. Five participants gave talks at the conference (speakers are marked with * below).

  • Alina Cojocaru (University of Illinois at Chicago)* 
  • Sumita Garai (Pennsylvania State University) 
  • Nathan Green (Texas A&M University)*
  • Zev Rosengarten (Stanford University)*
  • Qibin Shen (University of Rochester) 
  • Shuhui Shi (University of Rochester) 
  • Dinesh Thakur (University of Rochester)* 
  • Christelle Vincent (University of Vermont)* 
  • Guchao Zeng (Texas A&M University)

Among NSF funded participants, 3 were tenured or tenure-line faculty members at US universities (Cojocaru, Thakur, Vincent), and the other 6 were Ph.D. graduate students at the time of the conference. NSF funds were sufficient to cover airfare from US to Germany and most of local expenses for these participants.

This conference increased international collaboration between mathematicians from the United States, Europe, Asia, and Africa. A large number of participants were graduate students and junior researchers. The conference served as a career development opportunity for them, since interacting with top researchers provided a platform for communication for their subsequent quest on the job market. Five of the 27 talks at the conference were given by advanced doctoral students. The slides of 8 talks were posted on the conference website to allow for wide dissemination across the entire mathematical community.

Our friend and colleague David Goss was an invited speaker, but tragically passed away on April 4, 2017. We decided to dedicate the conference to his memory. Journal of Number theory edits a special issue dedicated to the memory of David Goss, the former editor in Chief of the Journal of Number Theory. The contents will be based in part on contributions by the participants of the conference. 

Overall, the conference was a great success, as is evidenced by the large number of participants and the number of requests for contributed talks that we received (we were able to accommodate only part of these requests).
Because of the rapid developments in the area of function field arithmetic, it was decided to hold a follow up conference at Centro di Ricerca Matematica in Pisa (Italy) in November 5-9, 2018. The title of this latter conference is New Developments in the Theory of Modular Forms over Function Fields and it is organized by the PI in collaboration with Florian Breuer, Ahmad El-Guindy, Federico Pellarin and Rudolph Perkins.
